fields.description:
I strongly feel that our documentation lack the full advertisement of {{eucanetd}} that this component really deserves. It is a critical piece of software that runs on the Node controller (NC) as well as the Cloud Controller (CLC) in Virtual Private cloud (VPC) network configuration.

The only mention we have of {{eucanetd}} as a "component" is here:

https://www.eucalyptus.com/docs/eucalyptus/4.1.0/index.html#install-guide/planning_edge.html

that says:

"In Edge networking mode, the component responsible for implementing Eucalyptus VM networking artifacts is running at the edge of a Eucalyptus deployment: the Node Controller (NC). Eucalyptus provides a stand-alone component called eucanetd in each NC. This componenent dynamically receives changing Eucalyptus networking views and is responsible for configuring the Linux machine on which the NC is running to reflect the latest view."

There is also a typo in the above statement for the word component. Anyways the point is to get more visibility for {{eucanetd}} in following locations:

https://www.eucalyptus.com/docs/eucalyptus/4.1.0/index.html#install-guide/euca_components.html
https://www.eucalyptus.com/docs/eucalyptus/4.1.0/index.html#install-guide/euca_architecture.html
https://www.eucalyptus.com/docs/eucalyptus/4.1.0/index.html#install-guide/component_understanding.html

In addition to this the {{EDGE}} talking page here https://www.eucalyptus.com/docs/eucalyptus/4.1.0/index.html#install-guide/planning_edge.html can also benefit with some more details on {{eucanetd}}

I propose a separate section altogether dedicated to {{eucanetd}} and how it works. 

Cheers,
Deependra
fields.summary: eucanetd does not feature in documentation

comments.body: Also relates to EUCA-10695, which was doc'd in only a release note in 4.1.2.

Related to eucanetd - 
https://eucalyptus.atlassian.net/wiki/pages/diffpagesbyversion.action?pageId=125730836&selectedPageVersions=11&selectedPageVersions=9 Mauricio’s edits
https://eucalyptus.atlassian.net/wiki/pages/viewpage.action?pageId=125730836 graphic includes eucanetd (green figure)

More things to do:
# add eucanetd to http://docs.hpcloud.com/eucalyptus/4.3.0/#install-guide/starting_euca_clc.html (similar to start NC topic, but for VPCMIDO mode)
# Per https://eucalyptus.atlassian.net/wiki/pages/viewpage.action?pageId=125730836
{quote}
Remove:
"The CC also manages the virtual machine networks in Managed and Managed (No VLAN) networking modes." from Cluster Controller description.
"The NC manages the virtual machine networks in Edge networking mode. The NC is also responsible for the management of the virtual network endpoint." from Node Controller description.
{quote}
# add eucanetd to CLC for VPCMIDO in http://docs.hpcloud.com/eucalyptus/4.3.0/#admin-guide/ops-monitoring.html
# add a troubleshooting topic (https://eucalyptus.atlassian.net/wiki/display/NET/EDGE+Networking+Overview has content) ...
# perhaps after this http://docs.hpcloud.com/eucalyptus/4.3.0/#troubleshooting-guide/ts_system.html networking troubleshooting, which needs a review
[~mbacchi] and [~tsugawa] please review the attached draft and provide your feedback. On track? Included some questions  where I was unsure.  [^About Eucanetd DRAFT1.pdf]

Added new topic:
* http://packages.release.eucalyptus-systems.com/documentation/master/#install-guide/eucanetd_about.html

Updated topics:
# http://packages.release.eucalyptus-systems.com/documentation/master/#install-guide/euca_components.html - updated CC and NC entries, added eucanetd
# updated diagram on the above page, adding eucanetd
# http://packages.release.eucalyptus-systems.com/documentation/master/#install-guide/starting_euca_clc.html - added step about eucanetd in VPCMIDO mode
# http://packages.release.eucalyptus-systems.com/documentation/master/#install-guide/starting_euca_cc.html - added step about eucanetd in MANAGED modes
# http://packages.release.eucalyptus-systems.com/documentation/master/#install-guide/starting_euca_nc.html - updated step about eucanetd to include MANAGED
# http://packages.release.eucalyptus-systems.com/documentation/master/#admin-guide/ops-monitoring.html - added eucanetd to CLC and CC, corrected NC entry
# http://packages.release.eucalyptus-systems.com/documentation/master/#admin-guide/ops_ts.html - elaborated on networking bullet, added eucanetd bullet
# http://packages.release.eucalyptus-systems.com/documentation/master/#troubleshooting-guide/ts_logs.html - added eucanetd.log entries for CLC, CC, NC (CHECK THESE for accuracy please)
# http://packages.release.eucalyptus-systems.com/documentation/master/#troubleshooting-guide/ts_system.html - added a eucanetd bullet, tweaked MANAGED bullet (ANYTHING ELSE we should add?)

Still TO DO FOR 4.4 (after the above content has been reviewed/finalized):
remove the 4.3 table from the 'about' topic
deprecated MANAGED modes in ALL the above topics
[~tsugawa] and [~mbacchi] please review the above referenced topics with eucanetd/networking updates. Let me know if you see any errors or omissions. (I saw one.)

Comments from a first pass (will likely need follow ups):

http://packages.release.eucalyptus-systems.com/documentation/master/#install-guide/euca_components.html

Figure beautification may be needed.
"Walrus is intended for light S3 usage and is a single host." - is Walrus a host? "deployed in a single host" ?
CLC is described as a server; CC and NC are described as programs (i.e., "must run" and "execute"); eucanetd is described as a service.
Consistency would be nice - is CLC/CC/NC a server? a Eucalyptus cloud component?
Perhaps a definition/note: CLC/CC/NC/SC are used to refer to the server hosting these programs, the programs themselves, or as a Eucalyptus component depending on the context.

http://packages.release.eucalyptus-systems.com/documentation/master/#install-guide/starting_euca_nc.html
Rephrase: "Note: For VPCMIDO networking mode, eucanetd is only on the CLC."
Is this note needed given that it is repeated elsewhere? "only runs" instead of "is only on"?

http://packages.release.eucalyptus-systems.com/documentation/master/#admin-guide/ops-monitoring.html
"Open Ports" is incomplete - refer to http://packages.release.eucalyptus-systems.com/documentation/master/#security-guide/security_firewalls.html

http://packages.release.eucalyptus-systems.com/documentation/master/#admin-guide/ops-monitoring.html
Monitoring typically has a different meaning.
This topic looks more aligned with something like "Verify Processes in Your Deployment".
The table describes what processes a healthy Eucalyptus deployment should have.
Do we need eucalyptus-cloud on CC and SC? Where are eucalyptus-cluster and eucalyptus-node?

http://packages.release.eucalyptus-systems.com/documentation/master/#admin-guide/ops_ts.html
Needs improvement/contents

http://packages.release.eucalyptus-systems.com/documentation/master/#troubleshooting-guide/ts_system.html
The last bullet that refers to euca-describe commands have nothing to do with "Network Information"

http://packages.release.eucalyptus-systems.com/documentation/master/troubleshooting-guide/ts_logs.html
"only in VPCMODE" -> "only in VPCMIDO mode"
"This log contains information about network health for network artifacts (iptables, ipsets, ebtables, dhcpd) related to the CLC (only in VPCMODE)."
"iptables, ipsets, ebtables, dhcp" are not involved, and they are not technically related to the CLC.
"This log contains information about network health managed by eucanetd running on CLC (only in VPCMIDO mode)" ?

"This log contains information about network health for network artifacts (iptables, ipsets, ebtables, dhcpd) related to the CC (only in MANAGED modes)."
"This log contains information about network health for network artifacts (iptables, ipsets, ebtables, dhcpd) managed by eucanetd running on CC (only in MANAGED modes)." ?

"This log contains information about network health for network artifacts (iptables, ipsets, ebtables, dhcpd) related to the NC (in EDGE and MANAGED modes)."
"This log contains information about network health for network artifacts (iptables, ipsets, ebtables, dhcpd) managed by eucanetd running on NC (in EDGE and MANAGED modes)." ?

cloud-exhaust.log | "This file is full of errors and warnings." - this does not sound accurate/good.

/var/log/messages contains logs not only from Eucalyptus, so the description will need to change.
For example, look for such and such logs in /var/log/messages
/var/log/messages | "This file contains DHCP bridge issues and general network-related issues" sounds like /var/log/messages only contains DHCP and network related issues (which is not true)

"Using Localized Fault Logs"
Describe why one would want to set "LOCALE=ru_RU"
e.g., "to set the system LOCALE to Russian..." (do we have Russian localized messages?)

Changes based on [~tsugawa] feedback:
# graphic is functional - waiting for new branding to work DOC-1542 and improve all the graphics with same style.
# components - in general, these are services that run on host machines; cleaned up the wording.
# VPCMIDO note on NC - was a stop-gap approved by you in 4.3; deleted the note.
# ports - cross-reference to the topic; deleted the column.
# monitoring - corrected the processes
# ops_ts - is an overview section, left as is (we can open a separate ticket to improve)
# ts_system - left as is (we can open a separate ticket to improve)
# logs - made corrections and updates; it is possible to localize (this was emphasized earlier in Euca product life, not so much now)

Also please check eucanetd mentions in the following topics - anything to change?
http://packages.release.eucalyptus-systems.com/documentation/master/#install-guide/planning_edge.html 
http://packages.release.eucalyptus-systems.com/documentation/master/#install-guide/preparing_firewalls.html
http://packages.release.eucalyptus-systems.com/documentation/master/#install-guide/installing_euca_release.html

With the above, I have added, updated, and searched for all references to eucanetd. Please let me know if you have any further changes for eucanetd. (If you have other than eucanetd edits, we should log separate tickets.) Thank you for your time.

In general, acronyms seems to be (re)defined in many places. Should we have a list of acronyms and stop defining everywhere in the text?

http://packages.release.eucalyptus-systems.com/documentation/master/#install-guide/planning_edge.html 

Some confusion on what is an NC. Not critical in this case, but what would "restart an NC" mean? restart eucalyptus-node service or reboot the server hosting NC service?

In Edge networking mode, the component responsible for implementing Eucalyptus VM networking artifacts is running at the edge of a Eucalyptus deployment: -the Node Controller (NC)- {color:red}the Linux machines acting as Node Controllers (i.e., that host Eucalyptus NC service){color}. {color:red}In each of such servers, a Eucalyptus -provides a- stand-alone component (service?) called eucanetd runs side-by-side with NC service.{color}{color:red} -This component- eucanetd -dynamically- receives dynamically changing{color} Eucalyptus networking views and is responsible for configuring the Linux -machine on which the NC is running- {color:red}networking subsystem{color} to reflect the latest view.

Edge Mode Requirements:
- There are references to NC and NC machine (and seems to mean the same thing)
- Same for CLC and Cloud Controller machine
- -the Cloud Controller machines- -> the Cloud Controller machine

Edge Mode Limitations:
- First bullet repeats first bullet of "Edge Mode Requirements" in a less clear way. Copy the text in the first bullet of requirements? Or just consider a requirement and not a limitation?

http://packages.release.eucalyptus-systems.com/documentation/master/#install-guide/installing_euca_release.html

There is no mention of eucanetd install (only that disabling libvirt default network allows eucanetd to start dhcpd process). If eucanetd is installed as a dependency, it may be a good idea to mention it ?

Perhaps it would be better to break the installation into sections that covers CLC, CC, NC, SC, eucanetd, euca2ools packages in separate blocks. Or, have a sample topology at the beginning and refer to it when describing the installation. The way it looks now it may be read as install everything on all servers.

[~tsugawa] 
# acronyms (and first-use rules in general) are a design challenge when you use DITA / reuse content in various ways. I agree and created DOC-2006
# edge topic updated
# install packages - are you saying that there should be a eucanetd install step? (I wondered about that in the PDF - we currently install eucanetd in one unlikely place in the docs) if so, does the new step 7 look reasonable?
# install in general - thank you for your very valid input; I added it to DOC-1615, which we will get back to at some point.

[~tsugawa] in addition to the above question (item #3), just noticing that these 2 topics do not mention eucanetd and they probably should:
http://builds.qa1.eucalyptus-systems.com/documentation/branch/master/#install-guide/planning_managed.html
http://builds.qa1.eucalyptus-systems.com/documentation/branch/master/#install-guide/planning_managed_novlan.html
... and with that, we should be finished. Yay!

[~kmeredith], step 7 look reasonable.

For MANAGED/MANAGED-NOVLAN, adapting the text from EDGE (feel free to edit/change):

In Managed networking mode, Eucalyptus VM networking artifacts are enforced at cluster level – i.e., on the Linux host machines acting as Cluster Controllers. On each CC host machine, a Eucalyptus stand-alone service, eucanetd, runs side-by-side with the CC service. The eucanetd service receives dynamically changing Eucalyptus networking views and is responsible for configuring the Linux networking subsystem to reflect the latest view. The eucanetd service also runs on Linux host machines acting as Node Controllers, and is responsible for maintaining the network path of instances to their corresponding CC.

In Managed (No VLAN) networking mode, Eucalyptus VM networking artifacts are enforced at cluster level – i.e., on the Linux host machines acting as Cluster Controllers. On each CC host machine, a Eucalyptus stand-alone service, eucanetd, runs side-by-side with the CC service. The eucanetd service receives dynamically changing Eucalyptus networking views and is responsible for configuring the Linux networking subsystem to reflect the latest view.

(Technically we do not need eucanetd on NCs in MANAGED-NOVLAN – not sure why we install and run [~mbacchi] ?).

Thanks, [~tsugawa] if MANAGED-NOVLAN does not need eucanetd on the NCs then I need to update the 4.3 table here:
http://builds.qa1.eucalyptus-systems.com/documentation/branch/master/#install-guide/eucanetd_about.html

[~mbacchi] please let me know the answer to this question. Thanks!

[~tsugawa] updated pages:
http://builds.qa1.eucalyptus-systems.com/documentation/branch/maint-4.3/#install-guide/planning_managed_novlan.html
http://builds.qa1.eucalyptus-systems.com/documentation/branch/maint-4.3/#install-guide/planning_managed.html

Let me know if we need to update the 4.3 table here:
http://builds.qa1.eucalyptus-systems.com/documentation/branch/master/#install-guide/eucanetd_about.html
(if eucanetd on the NC is not needed in Managed NO_VLAN mode - I need to add another column to separate the Managed modes in that case)

WRT Managed-NOVLAN: I was just checking the code (eucanetd_managednv.c) and noticed that there is no useful eucanetd activity in NCs - i.e., as the comment mentions, eucanetd can validate the bridge interface, but cannot do much if the bridge is not valid. So, the system should work without eucanetd running on NCs. Given the deprecation of Managed-NOVLAN mode, it is not worth the trouble of changing anything, though.

Managed-NOVLAN
http://builds.qa1.eucalyptus-systems.com/documentation/branch/maint-4.3/#install-guide/planning_managed_novlan.html

edits
The eucanetd service also runs on Linux host machines acting as Node Controllers (NC{color:red}s{color}), and is responsible for -maintaining the network path of instances to their corresponding CC- {color:red}basic network configuration checks{color}.

add requirement:
- Any DHCP server on the subnet must be configured not to serve Eucalyptus instances.

edits
If you plan to set up more than one cluster, you need to have a bridge {color:red}(between clusters){color} -for- {color:red}to enable{color} security groups to span the clusters.

add limitation:
- The machine that hosts the CC is a single point of failure for external VM network communication.
